Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CDS&E: Mining Physically Predictive Cosmological Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
By running detailed computer simulations, the investigators are working to understand how galaxies form. Because of the complexity of this problem, large computer simulations are needed to follow all the key physical processes. These investigators are developing a new approach for efficient modeling. The new methods have proved extremely successful in reproducing many of the observed properties of galaxies. The investigators will further improve their simulations to study a much wider range of galaxy types. They will push the frontiers of galaxy formation modeling on multiple fronts by including more physical processes and improving numerical accuracy. The new simulations will be used to study different sized galaxies from dwarf galaxies to galaxy halos ten times more massive than our Milky Way galaxy. The investigators will train students in computer modeling techniques that have a wide range of scientific and industrial applications. They will also produce film-quality animations produced from the new simulations, which will be the basis for education and outreach initiatives, including several planetariums. The new modules and optimizations for the simulation code will be publicly released, which will benefit not only astrophysics but also other disciplines, such as engineering.

The investigators lead the "Feedback In Realistic Environments" (FIRE) project and create sets of cosmological simulations of galaxy formation that explicitly model stellar feedback on the scale of individual star-forming regions. In these simulations feedback will be directly anchored to stellar evolution models, significantly improving their predictive power by reducing the reliance on adjustable parameters. The FIRE simulations have proven successful in matching stellar masses, galactic winds, and the dark matter distributions of dwarf galaxies. To reach larger audiences, the investigators plan to create new musical "sonifications" of the FIRE simulations. The sonifications will be performed at an annual concert and highlight time-dependent phenomena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF proposal supported the development and enabled the science of a next-generation of theoretical models for how galaxies and stars form and evolve. With the support of this grant, one of the largest theoretical astrophysics networks in astrophysics -- the Feedback In Realistic Environments (FIRE) collaboration -- was able to train and support a network of graduate students at a variety of institutions including not just the PI institutions (Caltech, Berkeley, Northwestern, and UC San Diego), but 13 other institutions, including nearly 100 astronomers (mostly graduate students and postdoctoral scholars) as well. Working directly with the PI at Caltech, several high school students, undergraduate students from a variety of different backgrounds and historically under-represented groups, were trained in computationational physics and astrophysics. They helped to develop state-of-the-art computer simulations following the dynamics of stars and dark matter and gas in galaxies, how it comes together to form stars, and how these processes interact with exotic processes such as the growth of super-massive black holes, magnetic fields, relativistic particles, and more. 

These students and postdocs led the development of new, massively-parallel computational codes. These codes were made public and used across a wide variety of fields, not just in astrophysics but also different material engineering and fluid dynamics applications. Within astrophysics, they were used to run a large suite of more than 100 simulations, incorporating detailed physics never before included in self-consistent models for how galaxies and stars form. 

With these tools, these students  and postdocs and the PI were able to show that some of the longest-standing challenges to our understanding of dark matter could in fact be explained with relatively "normal" physics. They also helped to explain decades-old mysteries in why galaxies have the shapes and sizes that they do, and why certain exotic galaxy types that were only recently discovered (such as "ultra-diffuse" or "ultra-faint" galaxies) form naturally in modern models. 

These simulations also fundamentally advanced our understanding of a wide variety of plasma physics processes, including how charged particles interact with magnetic fields, how these interations shape the surrounding medium, and how this interplay generates and shapes turbulence, of fundamental interest across a wide variety of space and fusion and other plasma physics fields. 

Four students supported by this grant completed Ph.D.'s at Caltech under the direct supervision of the PI and have gone on to STEM careers either in academia or data science fields. Four postdocs supported by the grant and under the PI's supervision have likewise continued to STEM careers. 

The results of this work led to a large number of publications: more than 70 major scientific publications in world-leading peer-reviewed astrophysical journals were published supported by this grant. Dozens of colloquiua, seminars, invited talks at international conferences and major conference proceedings were given by the PI or the students supported by this grant. 

In addition, the simulations developed for this were used in various outreach programs, including education programs and recruitment of high school students and teachers in arts and media design, public talks in a wide variety of venues, planetarium shows and feature films. These reached audiences far beyond academic astrophysics.
